problem: Given that $\triangle+q=59$ and $(\triangle+q)+q=106$, what is the value of $\triangle$?
solution: Substituting $\triangle + q = 59$ into the second equation gives $59 + q = 106$, so $q= 106-59 = 47$.  Substituting $q=47$ into $\triangle + q =59$ gives $\triangle + 47 = 59$, so $\triangle = \boxed{12}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Subtract $\triangle+q$ from both sides of the second equation to get $q=106-(\triangle+q)$.
Step 2: Simplify the right side of the equation, $q=106-(\triangle+q)$, to $q=106-\triangle-q$.
Step 3: Combine like terms on the right side of the equation, $q=106-\triangle-q$, to get $q=106-\triangle- q$ which becomes $2q=106-\triangle$.
Step 4: Add $\triangle$ to both sides of the equation, $2q=106-\triangle$, to get $2q+\triangle=106$.
Step 5: Subtract $2q$ from both sides of the equation, $2q+\triangle=106$, to get $\triangle=106-2q$.
Step 6: Substitute $\triangle=106-2q$ into the first equation $\triangle+q=59$ to get $106-2q+q=59$.
Step 7: Simplify the equation $106-2q+q=59$ to $106-q=59$.
Step 8: Subtract 106 from both sides of the equation, $106-q=59$, to get $-q=-47$.
Step 9: Multiply both sides of the equation, $-q=-47$, by $-1$ to get $q=47$.
Step 10: Substitute $q=47$ into the equation $\triangle=106-2q$ to get $\triangle=106-2(47)$.

Step 2: Simplify the right side of the equation, $q=106-(\triangle+q)$, to $q=106-\triangle-q$.
Step 3: Combine like terms on the right side of the equation, $q=106-\triangle-q$, to get $q=106-\triangle- q$ which becomes $2q=106-\triangle$.
Step 4: Add $\triangle$ to both sides of the equation, $2q=106-\triangle$, to get $2q+\triangle=106$.
Step 5: Subtract $2q$ from both sides of the equation, $2q+\triangle=106$, to get $\triangle=106-2q$.
Step 6: Substitute $\triangle=106-2q$ into the first equation $\triangle+q=59$ to get $106-2q+q=59$.
Step 8: Subtract 106 from both sides of the equation, $106-q=59$, to get $-q=-47$.
Step 9: Multiply both sides of the equation, $-q=-47$, by $-1$ to get $q=47$.
Step 10: Substitute $q=47$ into the equation $\triangle=106-2q$ to get $\triangle=106-2(47)$.

Step 2: Simplify the right side of the equation, $q=106-(\triangle+q)$, to $q=106-\triangle-q$.
Step 3: Combine like terms on the right side of the equation, $q=106-\triangle-q$, to get $q=106-\triangle- q$ which becomes $2q=106-\triangle$.
Step 4: Add $\triangle$ to both sides of the equation, $2q=106-\triangle$, to get $2q+\triangle=106$.
Step 5: Subtract $2q$ from both sides of the equation, $2q+\triangle=106$, to get $\triangle=106-2q$.
Step 6: Substitute $\triangle=106-2q$ into the first equation $\triangle+q=59$ to get $106-2q+q=59$.
Step 8: Subtract 106 from both sides of the equation, $106-q=59$, to get $-q=-47$.
Step 9: Multiply both sides of the equation, $-q=-47$, by $-1$ to get $q=47$.
Step 10: Substitute $q=47$ into the equation $\triangle=106-2q$ to get $\triangle=106-2(47)$.
